questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of photophobia and pruritus on the periocular area of the right eye. He also had crusts over the eyelashes of the right eye that morning. The boy has a history of asthma and atopic dermatitis. His medications include inhaled steroids and salbutamol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and redness of the affected eye with watery discharge. There are multiple vesicles with an erythematous base located on the upper and lower eyelids. Visual acuity test shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum virus is a cause of chronic follicular conjunctivitis, a condition that usually manifests with chronic unilateral ocular irritation and mucoid discharge. The virus causes typical umbilicated nodules which can be found on the lid margin and possibly on other areas of the skin. The patient, in this case, presents with acute conjunctivitis and a rash characteristic of a different disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis is the leading cause of neonatal conjunctivitis (or ophthalmia neonatorum). Infection is usually caused by exposure to contaminated maternal discharge, typically during birth, and patients present with mucopurulent discharge. Infection of older patients leads to granular conjunctivitis (trachoma) and can cause blindness. Common findings include follicles and papillae on the conjunctiva as well as scarring and corneal damage later in the course of the disease. These features are inconsistent with this patient's watery discharge and a periorbital rash.

C) INCORRECT:

Adenoviruses are the most common cause of viral (nonpurulent) conjunctivitis. The disease is highly contagious and commonly occurs in small outbreaks. Typical symptoms include itching, serous discharge, severe foreign body sensation, and conjunctival hyperemia, as mentioned in this case. However, adenovirus conjunctivitis typically affects both eyes, either simultaneously or in sequence. Most importantly, although it often presents with signs of systemic infection, such as pharyngitis, fever, and lymphadenopathy, it is not associated with a vesicular rash.

D) INCORRECT:

Enterovirus 70 is a picornavirus that causes acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Patients present with a sudden onset of pain, periorbital swelling, subconjunctival hemorrhages, and conjunctival injection. In most cases, the infection involves both eyes. Though the patient, in this case, presents with conjunctival injection, a periocular rash is characteristic of a different disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute infection with varicella-zoster virus sometimes causes conjunctivitis. Patients are usually children and present with additional symptoms such as fever and a generalized vesiculopustular rash. The conjunctiva can also be affected in reactivation of the latent virus in the trigeminal ganglion (herpes zoster ophthalmicus). These patients are often older or immunosuppressed and present with a headache, fever, and a vesicular rash along the trigeminal dermatome. None of these features are present in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Bacterial conjunctivitis is the most common form of infectious conjunctivitis in children. Common pathogens include Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis. Infection usually manifests as purulent conjunctivitis with thick yellow, white, or green discharge, which is inconsistent with this patient's nonpurulent conjunctivitis and watery discharge.

G) CORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can cause nonpurulent conjunctivitis, which manifests with photophobia, pruritus on the periocular area, crusts over the eyelashes, conjunctival injection, redness, and watery discharge from the eye. HSV-1 conjunctivitis is more common in children and adults, while HSV-2 often affects neonates. HSV conjunctivitis is usually unilateral and often manifests with a vesicular rash and corneal involvement (e.g., dendritic keratitis). Additionally, patients with a history of atopic dermatitis are particularly susceptible to HSV conjunctivitis.

HSV conjunctivitis is usually self-limited and resolves within 2 weeks, although neonatal forms can be fatal. The gold standard for diagnosis of HSV conjunctivitis is cell culture. However, typical cases in neonates or immunosuppressed patients should be treated without laboratory confirmation, as testing may delay treatment. In adults, treatment is only indicated in corneal involvement. Therapy usually consists of topical, oral, and/or IV acyclovir, depending on the severity of the disease, the age of the patient, and underlying conditions (e.g., immunosuppression).
Image Description:

Left eye

The conjunctival blood vessels are dilated (injection). There is no purulent discharge.

This finding is consistent with viral conjunctivitis.

H) INCORRECT:

Allergic conjunctivitis manifests with itchiness, chemosis (swelling of the conjunctiva), and serous secretion. Despite its association with atopic conditions such as asthma and atopic dermatitis, symptoms of allergic conjunctivitis are usually milder than those of infectious conjunctivitis and do not include a vesicular rash.
questions.hint: What infection associated with multiple vesicles are patients with atopic dermatitis prone to?

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 4-day history of irritation and redness in both eyes. Her symptoms initially started in the left eye and progressed to involve both eyes within 24 hours. She presents with profuse tearing and reports that her eyes are sticky and difficult to open in the morning. She was diagnosed with asthma 2 years ago and has been admitted to the hospital for acute exacerbations three times since then. Current medications include inhaled beclomethasone, inhaled albuterol, and montelukast. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Physical examination reveals a tender left preauricular lymph node. There is chemosis and diffuse erythema of the bulbar conjunctiva bilaterally with watery discharge. Slit-lamp examination shows a follicular reaction in both palpebral conjunctivae and diffuse, fine epithelial keratitis of both corneas. Corneal sensation is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Supportive therapy with artificial tears and cold compresses is the most appropriate treatment for uncomplicated epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, a self-limiting adenovirus infection that typically resolves completely within one week. Due to the highly contagious nature of this adenovirus infection, prevention is critical, especially in healthcare settings.

See “Overview of conjunctivitis subtypes in children and adults” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral cetirizine is used to treat symptoms of allergic rhinitis. The ocular manifestations of allergic rhinitis may also include conjunctival erythema with watery discharge, but almost always include immediate bilateral involvement and prominent itchiness, none of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, lymphadenopathy is not a feature of allergic rhinitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical prednisolone acetate is used to minimize ocular inflammation in cases of severe allergic conjunctivitis, autoimmune conditions such as uveitis or severe bacterial keratitis, and after ophthalmic surgery. Steroids are not indicated for viral infections such as epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral acyclovir is the first-line treatment for herpes simplex keratitis, which usually manifests with unilateral conjunctivitis accompanied by a foreign body sensation. The classic finding on ocular examination is linearly branching corneal ulcers (dendritic ulcers). This patient has bilateral conjunctivitis with watery discharge, making herpes simplex infection unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Natamycin is an appropriate treatment for fungal eye infections, which are very rare. The major risk factor for development of these infections is a traumatic eye injury with fungal contamination. Symptoms besides erythema include intense pain, photophobia, and purulent drainage. Since this patient does not have severe pain or photophobia and has no history of eye injury, fungal infection is highly unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Topical moxifloxacin is reserved for use in moderate to severe bacterial conjunctivitis, which manifests with erythematous conjunctiva, purulent discharge, upper lid papillae on slit-lamp examination, and possibly fever and lymphadenopathy. This patient has copious watery discharge and follicles on slit-lamp examination, meaning bacterial conjunctivitis is unlikely.

G) INCORRECT:

Topical erythromycin is an appropriate treatment for mild bacterial conjunctivitis, which manifests with erythematous conjunctiva, purulent discharge, and upper lid papillae on slit-lamp examination. This patient has copious watery ocular discharge, lymphadenopathy, and follicles on slit-lamp examination, all of which make mild bacterial conjunctivitis unlikely.
questions.hint: Redness and profuse watery discharge which start in one eye and rapidly spread to the other, preauricular lymphadenopathy, low-grade fever, and signs of corneal inflammation are consistent with epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man presents with increasing redness, irritation, and discharge that began in the right eye 3 days ago and in the left eye yesterday. He describes swollen eyelids and recalls having a mild sore throat one week ago. He has no significant medical history and does not take any medications.
Which one of the following clinical findings, if present, would be more consistent with a viral rather than bacterial etiology for this patient’s conjunctivitis?

choices.text: Complete redness of the conjunctiva, obscuring tarsal vessels

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Viral conjunctivitis is typically characterized by redness, burning, and irritation in one eye that spreads to the other eye. The most common culprit is adenovirus, which may also cause a concomitant upper respiratory illness. Examination may show watery discharge, edematous or ecchymotic eyelids, conjunctival follicles and injection, subconjunctival hemorrhage, or corneal subepithelial infiltrates. Classic teaching suggests that preauricular lymph nodes are often palpable and tender. However, in a 2015 systematic review, this sign was not found to be as specific as originally believed, because it can also be seen in chlamydial and toxic conjunctivitis as well as bartonella infection.

Findings that increase the probability of a positive bacterial culture include complete redness of the conjunctiva obscuring the tarsal vessels, observed purulent discharge, matting of both eyes in the morning, and onset during winter or spring.

Patients with viral conjunctivitis are contagious while symptomatic, and contact precautions are recommended. Routine empiric treatment with topical antibiotics is not recommended because these drops are not effective against the causative viruses; furthermore, they may exacerbate symptoms if the preparations contain preservatives that irritate the eye.

Key learning point: A red eye with clear, watery discharge is most consistent with a viral (rather than bacterial) conjunctivitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Findings that increase the probability of a positive bacterial culture include complete redness of the conjunctiva obscuring the tarsal vessels.

C) INCORRECT:

Findings that increase the probability of a positive bacterial culture include observed purulent discharge.

D) INCORRECT:

Findings that increase the probability of a positive bacterial culture include onset during winter or spring.

E) INCORRECT:

Itching can be seen in all forms of conjunctivitis but is most commonly associated with allergic conjunctivitis. It is not helpful in distinguishing between viral and bacterial causes of conjunctivitis.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy presents in the summertime with bilateral eye redness and a watery discharge. He has no previous history of such symptoms. His mother reports that his eyes seemed swollen when he awoke that morning and that he has had some nasal congestion for the past few days. He has been attending a summer camp where several children have been reported to have similar symptoms. He has no new exposures and no history of asthma, allergies, or eczema.
His temperature is 37.2°C, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. His respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 100% while he breathes ambient air.
He appears to be in some discomfort and is rubbing his eyes. He has periorbital swelling and bilateral conjunctival injection with a watery discharge (figure). He appears to be moving his extraocular muscles appropriately but is not fully cooperative with the assessment. There is mild cervical and preauricular lymphadenopathy. The remainder of his examination is unremarkable.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Herpetic keratitis is usually unilateral and characterized by pain, photophobia, blurred vision, tearing, and redness. There is typically a thin, watery discharge and accompanying vesicular skin lesions of the lids; it may also be accompanied by preauricular adenopathy. The infection may progress to punctate keratitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease is characterized by fever for at least 5 days plus a nonexudative, limbic-sparing conjunctivitis, mucous membrane changes, rash, extremity changes, and a unilateral lymph node that is greater than 1.5 cm.

C) CORRECT:

Conjunctivitis is the most likely diagnosis in a patient with red eyes and discharge; it is often a self-limiting process. More-worrisome diagnoses can masquerade as conjunctivitis, so clinicians should be sure to take a careful history, including changes in visual acuity, photophobia, significant pain, lack of response to therapy, and history of herpes simplex eye disease.

Discerning viral conjunctivitis from bacterial conjunctivitis can be difficult. Patients with viral conjunctivitis typically present with acutely red eyes and a watery or seromucous discharge throughout the day; they may also have photophobia and a foreign-body sensation. The infection is often bilateral. Viral conjunctivitis is typically caused by an adenovirus and may be associated with other symptoms such as cough, pharyngitis, and rhinorrhea, as in this case. Preauricular adenopathy can be associated with a viral conjunctivitis but is not diagnostic. Factors associated with a high likelihood of negative bacterial culture in children with acute conjunctivitis include age 6 or older, presentation in April through November, nonpurulent or watery discharge, and absence of morning gluing of the eyes.

In contrast, patients with bacterial conjunctivitis typically present with a mucopurulent or purulent discharge in addition to burning, irritation, and tearing. Purulent discharge and morning gluing or crusting make bacterial conjunctivitis more likely. Conjunctival swelling may be found but is not specific for bacterial conjunctivitis. Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae are the most common causative agents in children.

Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis is a type of very contagious viral conjunctivitis associated with corneal subepithelial infiltrates and reduced vision. Because of potential permanent vision loss, affected patients should be referred to an ophthalmologist.

Key learning point: A summertime presentation of bilateral eye redness, watery discharge, periorbital swelling, and nasal congestion in a patient with no new exposures and no history of asthma, allergies, or eczema is most consistent with diagnosis of viral conjunctivitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Allergic conjunctivitis is a seasonal condition that is characterized by intermittent bouts of itchy eyes with tearing, redness, and mild eyelid swelling. Patients with allergic conjunctivitis often have other atopic conditions, such as eczema; there may be a mild stringy discharge.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with bacterial conjunctivitis typically present with a mucopurulent or purulent discharge in addition to burning, irritation, and tearing.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents with increasing redness, irritation, and discharge that began in the right eye 3 days ago and in the left eye yesterday. He describes swollen eyelids and recalls having a mild sore throat one week ago. He has no significant medical history and does not take any medications.
Which one of the following clinical findings, if present, would be more consistent with a viral rather than bacterial etiology for this patient’s conjunctivitis?

choices.text: Complete redness of the conjunctiva, obscuring tarsal vessels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Complete redness of the conjunctiva obscuring the tarsal vessels is more commonly associated with bacterial than viral conjunctivitis.

B) CORRECT:

Viral conjunctivitis is typically characterized by redness, burning, and irritation in one eye that spreads to the other eye. The most common culprit is adenovirus, which may also cause a concomitant upper respiratory illness. Examination may show watery discharge, edematous or ecchymotic eyelids, conjunctival follicles and injection, subconjunctival hemorrhage, or corneal subepithelial infiltrates. Classic teaching suggests that preauricular lymph nodes are often palpable and tender. However, in a 2015 systematic review, this sign was not found to be as specific as originally believed, because it can also be seen in chlamydial and toxic conjunctivitis as well as bartonella infection.

Findings that increase the probability of a positive bacterial culture include complete redness of the conjunctiva obscuring the tarsal vessels, observed purulent discharge, matting of both eyes in the morning, and onset during winter or spring. Itching can be seen in all forms of conjunctivitis but is most commonly associated with allergic conjunctivitis. It is not helpful in distinguishing between viral and bacterial causes of conjunctivitis.

Patients with viral conjunctivitis are contagious while symptomatic, and contact precautions are recommended. Routine empiric treatment with topical antibiotics is not recommended because these drops are not effective against the causative viruses; furthermore, they may exacerbate symptoms if the preparations contain preservatives that irritate the eye.

Key learning point: A red eye with clear, watery discharge is most consistent with a viral (rather than bacterial) conjunctivitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Observed purulent discharge is more commonly associated with bacterial than viral conjunctivitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Onset during winter months is more commonly associated with bacterial than viral conjunctivitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Itching can be seen in all forms of conjunctivitis but is most commonly associated with allergic conjunctivitis. It is not helpful in distinguishing between viral and bacterial causes of conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a fever, runny nose, and red eyes for the past 2 days. Several other children at the girl's summer day camp have similar symptoms. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.66°F). Physical examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection, nasal congestion, an erythematous posterior oropharynx, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus infections can affect the eyes and typically manifest with a unilateral painful red eye. Other symptoms may include pain, watery eye discharge, and blurred vision. This patient’s bilateral presentation as well as fever and upper respiratory symptoms make this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Parainfluenza virus infections are a major cause of laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) and other upper and lower respiratory tract infections. They are not associated with conjunctivitis.

C) CORRECT:

Adenovirus infection often manifests as a febrile upper respiratory tract infection, which can include symptoms of the common cold, pharyngitis, tonsillitis, conjunctivitis, and (in rare instances) otitis media. Cervical and preauricular lymphadenopathy are common. Most infections are self-limited and can be managed symptomatically. Adenovirus infection is highly contagious and can occur at any time during the year, but outbreaks are most common in spring and early summer. Community outbreaks have been associated with swimming pools and shared equipment. Proper hand hygiene — as well as contact and droplet precautions when treating hospitalized patients — can help reduce spread of the virus. Polymerase chain-reaction testing is available for rapid diagnosis of adenovirus infection, but this testing is usually reserved for hospitalized or critically ill patients.

Key learning point: In a child, the most likely cause of an upper respiratory tract infection with pharyngitis, tonsillitis, and exudative conjunctivitis is adenovirus infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease (KD) is an acute, vasculitic illness of young children that may manifest with fever, conjunctivitis, and cervical lymphadenopathy. However, the diagnosis of typical KD requires a fever of 5 or more days plus at least four of the following characteristics: nonexudative conjunctivitis, oropharyngeal mucosal changes, edema or peeling of the extremities, a polymorphous rash, and a large, often unilateral, cervical lymph node. KD is not associated with nasal congestion. Although clinicians should always maintain a high index of suspicion for KD, this patient does not meet the diagnostic criteria at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Moraxella catarrhalis infection typically manifests as sinusitis. On rare occasions, it has been associated with conjunctivitis in neonates, but it is not a cause of conjunctivitis in older children.

questions.text: You are seeing a 7-year-old boy in the emergency department who has a 2-day history of photophobia and pruritus around the right eye. This morning, his caregiver noticed crusts over the eyelashes of the right eye. He has a history of asthma and atopic dermatitis, and his medications include inhaled steroids and salbutamol. His immunizations are up-to-date. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is conjunctival injection and redness of the right eye with watery discharge. Multiple vesicles with an erythematous base are present on the upper and lower eyelids. Visual acuity is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can cause nonpurulent conjunctivitis, which manifests with photophobia, pruritus on the periocular area, crusts over the eyelashes, conjunctival injection, redness, and watery discharge from the eye. HSV-1 conjunctivitis is more common in children and adults, while HSV-2 often affects neonates. HSV conjunctivitis is usually unilateral and often manifests with a vesicular rash and corneal involvement (e.g., dendritic keratitis). Additionally, patients with a history of atopic dermatitis are particularly susceptible to HSV conjunctivitis.

HSV conjunctivitis is usually self-limited and resolves within 2 weeks, although neonatal forms can be fatal. The gold standard for diagnosis of HSV conjunctivitis is cell culture. However, typical cases in neonates or immunosuppressed patients should be treated without laboratory confirmation, as testing may delay treatment. In adults, treatment is only indicated in corneal involvement. Therapy usually consists of topical, oral, and/or IV acyclovir, depending on the severity of the disease, the age of the patient, and underlying conditions (e.g., immunosuppression).

Key learning point: Herpes simplex virus conjunctivitis often presents as unilateral, nonpurulent conjunctivitis with periocular vesicles, especially in children with atopic dermatitis.
Image Description:

Left eye

The conjunctival blood vessels are dilated (injection). There is no purulent discharge.

This finding is consistent with viral conjunctivitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Adenoviruses are the most common cause of viral (nonpurulent) conjunctivitis. The disease is highly contagious and commonly occurs in small outbreaks. Typical symptoms include itching, serous discharge, severe foreign body sensation, and conjunctival hyperemia, as mentioned in this case. However, adenovirus conjunctivitis typically affects both eyes, either simultaneously or in sequence. Most importantly, although it often presents with signs of systemic infection, such as pharyngitis, fever, and lymphadenopathy, it is not associated with a vesicular rash.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute infection with varicella-zoster virus sometimes causes conjunctivitis. Patients are usually children and present with additional symptoms such as fever and a generalized vesiculopustular rash. The conjunctiva can also be affected in reactivation of the latent virus in the trigeminal ganglion (herpes zoster ophthalmicus). These patients are often older or immunosuppressed and present with a headache, fever, and a vesicular rash along the trigeminal dermatome. None of these features are present in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Allergic conjunctivitis manifests with itchiness, chemosis (swelling of the conjunctiva), and serous secretion. Despite its association with atopic conditions such as asthma and atopic dermatitis, symptoms of allergic conjunctivitis are usually milder than those of infectious conjunctivitis and do not include a vesicular rash.

E) INCORRECT:

Bacterial conjunctivitis is the most common form of infectious conjunctivitis in children. Common pathogens include Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis. Infection usually manifests as purulent conjunctivitis with thick yellow, white, or green discharge, which is inconsistent with this patient's nonpurulent conjunctivitis and watery discharge.
questions.hint: What infection associated with multiple vesicles are patients with atopic dermatitis prone to?

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-year-old girl in the emergency department who is brought in by her mother because of a 2-day history of fever, runny nose, and red eyes. Several children at her summer day camp have similar symptoms. Her temperature is 38.7°C. On examination, she has bilateral conjunctival injection, nasal congestion, an erythematous posterior oropharynx, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Moraxella catarrhalis infection typically manifests as sinusitis. On rare occasions, it has been associated with conjunctivitis in neonates, but it is not a cause of conjunctivitis in older children.

B) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus infections can affect the eyes and typically manifest with a unilateral painful red eye. Other symptoms may include pain, watery eye discharge, and blurred vision. This patient’s bilateral presentation as well as fever and upper respiratory symptoms make this diagnosis unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

Adenovirus infection often manifests as a febrile upper respiratory tract infection, which can include symptoms of the common cold, pharyngitis, tonsillitis, conjunctivitis, and (in rare instances) otitis media. Cervical and preauricular lymphadenopathy are common. Most infections are self-limited and can be managed symptomatically. Adenovirus infection is highly contagious and can occur at any time during the year, but outbreaks are most common in spring and early summer. Community outbreaks have been associated with swimming pools and shared equipment. Proper hand hygiene — as well as contact and droplet precautions when treating hospitalized patients — can help reduce spread of the virus. Polymerase chain-reaction testing is available for rapid diagnosis of adenovirus infection, but this testing is usually reserved for hospitalized or critically ill patients.

Key learning point: In a child, the most likely cause of an upper respiratory tract infection with pharyngitis, tonsillitis, and exudative conjunctivitis is adenovirus infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Parainfluenza virus infections are a major cause of laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) and other upper and lower respiratory tract infections. They are not associated with conjunctivitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease (KD) is an acute, vasculitic illness of young children that may manifest with fever, conjunctivitis, and cervical lymphadenopathy. However, the diagnosis of typical KD requires a fever of 5 or more days plus at least four of the following characteristics: nonexudative conjunctivitis, oropharyngeal mucosal changes, edema or peeling of the extremities, a polymorphous rash, and a large, often unilateral, cervical lymph node. KD is not associated with nasal congestion. Although clinicians should always maintain a high index of suspicion for KD, this patient does not meet the diagnostic criteria at this time.

questions.text: A 32-year-old health care worker presents with bilateral conjunctival injection and mild tearing that began 4 days ago. The patient reports watery discharge without crusting and denies significant pain or vision changes. Physical examination shows bilateral conjunctival erythema without purulent discharge, normal visual acuity, and no corneal involvement on fluorescein staining. A colleague was recently treated for similar symptoms. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation (bilateral watery discharge, conjunctival injection, no purulent discharge, no corneal involvement, normal visual acuity) is consistent with viral conjunctivitis. Viral conjunctivitis is typically self-limited and requires only supportive therapy with artificial tears and cold compresses for symptom relief.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate ophthalmology referral is not necessary for this presentation. The patient has normal visual acuity, no corneal involvement, and no red flag features such as severe pain, photophobia, or vision changes. Referral may be indicated if symptoms persist beyond 2–3 weeks or complications develop.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids should be avoided in suspected viral conjunctivitis, particularly when herpes simplex virus cannot be ruled out. Steroids can worsen viral infections and are not recommended as first-line therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical antiviral therapy is not routinely indicated for viral conjunctivitis. Most cases are caused by adenovirus, which does not respond to available topical antivirals.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics are not indicated in this patient. The bilateral watery discharge without purulent material and normal visual acuity suggest viral rather than bacterial conjunctivitis.
